title: Gottfried Ephraim Scheibel
text:
Gottfried Ephraim Scheibel (1696–1759) was a German <a href="theologian">theologian</a> and writer about music.
Scheibel studied theology in <a href="Leipzig">Leipzig</a> and from 1736 taught at the Elizabeth-Gymnasium in his home town of <a href="Breslau">Breslau</a>.
Scheibel's most famous <a href="treatise">treatise</a>, "Zufällige Gedancken von der Kirchenmusic" (Random Thoughts about Church Music), was published in 1721. It presents a strong defense of the role of music in the <a href="Lutheran%20Church">Lutheran Church</a> service, in particular music derived from <a href="opera">opera</a>. By way of example, he demonstrates the use of the parody technique—replacing secular texts with sacred ones, while keeping the music the same—using the music of <a href="Georg%20Philipp%20Telemann">Georg Philipp Telemann</a>.
